docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN you think about the economic issues facing the next president, you have to wonder why either candidate wants the job. There are the outsize budget deficits, high levels of private debt, a soaring trade deficit, growing numbers of Americans without health insurance, a possible bust in the housing bubble and an expansion that is not creating enough jobs and is probably already tapering to a crawl. But at least these issues have come up in the campaign. One issue that has not is the corporate scandals that rocked the nation two years ago. Now Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general, has uncovered another dark hole of apparent corporate wrongdoing among the nation's largest, most respected insurance companies.

headline.main: Where economists stand, or don't stand, on the issue of corporate scandals.

docs.snippet: In the push for greater regulation after the corporate scandals, economists are notably absent.

docs.lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater is freezing pay, cutting positions and canceling tour performances in a wave of cost-cutting measures that it says are putting the company back on the road to financial health. About 50 staff members will take a one-week furlough without pay, and many will not receive raises this year. Thanksgiving-week performances at the Orange County Performing Arts Center in California were canceled because of the high cost of putting on shows during a holiday. And the company's general manager was dismissed in a move that the troupe said was among cost-saving measures imposed even as the company has grown in dancers, number of performances and time spent touring.

headline.main: Ballet Theater Trims Costs, Trying to Keep the Cuts Offstage

docs.abstract: American Ballet Theater, taking cost-cutting measures, is freezing pay, cutting positions and canceling tour performances; about 50 staff members will take one-week furlough without pay and many will not receive raises this year; chief financial officer Rachel Pivnick says chronic budget deficit dropped from $1.3 million to 'well under' $1 million in fiscal 2004 (M)
docs.snippet: The troupe is freezing pay, cutting positions and canceling tours in a wave of measures that it says are putting the company back on the road to financial health.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE young man in the emergency room of Yale-New Haven Hospital had not been driving. He had toppled off the back of a pickup truck. But when the resident overseeing his care approached Dr. Gail D'Onofrio, his supervisor, with a report, she had one question: ''Did you screen him?'' ''Screen him'' meant ask about his drinking habits, but the resident had not. It turned out the young man had drunk 8 to 10 beers, Dr. D'Onofrio recalled. Which meant it was time for The Conversation.
docs.abstract: Dr Gail D'Onofrio of Yale-New Haven Hospital is among health experts who believe emergency room doctors should talk with patients, and not only in automobile cases, about family medical histories and drinking habits; estimates suggest 25 percent of patients in emergency rooms for trauma injuries are drunk and many of others are found on further evaluation to have drinking problems; study shows charges are filed against fewer than third of injured drivers who are medically drunk, suggesting emergency rooms have become unintended refuge for drunk drivers (special section, Cars) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, the parents of a Harvard student told Dr. Richard Kadison, the chief of the university's mental health service, that they suspected their daughter had a serious drug problem. ''The student in question argued that, although she needed some help, her problem was not substance abuse,'' Dr. Kadison said. ''From my standpoint, the problem was not who's right and who's wrong or what's the diagnosis, but whether she is getting the right help.''

headline.main: The Dorms May Be Great, But How's the Counseling?

docs.abstract: Record numbers of American college students are experiencing mental distress and seeking help at university counseling centers; National Survey of Counseling Center Directors annual report show that number of students taking psychiatric medications rose to 24.5 percent in 2003-2004 from just 17 percent in 2000 and 9 percent in 1994; students and parents are encouraged to research counseling services and mental health coverage before selecting university; most common types of disorders and methods of treatment for college students discussed; parental knowledge of problem is not guaranteed by most universities, but most will inform parent if student needs hospitalization; graph; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: Given the prevalence of emotional difficulties on campus, it pays to find out, before choosing a college, what mental health services are available.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NATIONAL SURVEY OF COUNSELING CENTER DIRECTORS

docs.lead_paragraph: Marsh & McLennan Chief Steps Down Amid Inquiry Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the chief executive and chairman of the insurance broker Marsh & McLennan, stepped down, less than two weeks after his company was accused of cheating customers.
docs.snippet: Marsh & McLennan Chief Steps Down Amid Inquiry  Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the chief executive and chairman of the insurance broker Marsh & McLennan, stepped down, less than two weeks after his company was accused of cheating customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.S. Ruling Alters Status Of Some Iraq Detainees A new legal opinion by the Bush administration has concluded for the first time that some non-Iraqi prisoners captured by American forces in Iraq are not entitled to the protections of the Geneva Conventions, administration officials said. A1 Iraqi officials opened an investigation into the role played by infiltrators in the ambush on Sunday that left 49 Iraqi national guard trainees dead amid growing indications that insurgents are being supplied inside information about the movements of Iraqi security forces. Meanwhile, fresh violence in Baghdad struck coalition troops. A11 Sharon Opens Gaza Debate Prime Minister Ariel Sharon opened a two-day parliamentary debate with a vow to see through his controversial plan to unilaterally remove all 21 Israeli settlements from the Gaza Strip. Mr. Sharon's speech was greeted with noise and catcalls, but Mr. Sharon is expected to prevail in the vote this evening. A3 China May Reopen Rights Talks Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, following a morning of meetings with Chinese leaders, said China had agreed to discuss the American request for a new dialogue over the detention of Chinese citizens without due process and other human rights violations. A7 Mystery of Mexican Murders A federal report found little evidence that most of the scores of women who have been murdered around Ciudad Juarez over the last decade were victims of gangsters or serial killers, as many women's groups contend. The report immediately drew fire from women's groups in the city. A8 Spain Blames Syrian in Attack A Syrian jailed since 2001 and thought to be a major operative for Al Qaeda, Imad Eddin Barakat Yarkas, also known as Abu Dahdah, was identified as the prime mover behind the March 11 terror attacks in Madrid, a high-ranking intelligence official told the Spanish Parliament. A8 NATIONAL A14-23 White House Addresses Missing Explosives in Iraq The White House sought to explain the disappearance in Iraq of 380 tons of high explosives that American forces were supposed to secure as Senator John Kerry seized on the missing cache as ''one of the great blunders of Iraq'' and said President Bush's ''incredible incompetence'' had put American troops at risk. A1 Campaigning with Senator John Kerry in Philadelphia, former President Bill Clinton told a crowd of 80,000 that ''in eight days, John Kerry's going to make America the Comeback Country.'' A1 Justice Rehnquist Hospitalized The Supreme Court announced that Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, 80, has been hospitalized since Friday for treatment of thyroid cancer and has undergone a tracheotomy in connection with the disease. A1 Immigration Measure in Arizona A proposition before Arizona's voters would require proof of citizenship when registering to vote and would deny illegal immigrants public benefits that are not federally mandated. Opponents contend that the measure will increase bureaucracy and violate privacy rights. A14 Parties Collect $1 Billion The Republican and Democratic parties raised more than $1 billion through mid-October, beating their total during the same period in the 2000 election, when the parties could accept soft money. A21 State Hate-Crime Law Revoked The Georgia Supreme Court unanimously struck down the state's 4-year-old hate-crimes law, saying it was ''unconstitutionally vague.'' A18 Scientist Faults Administration A top NASA climate expert who twice briefed Vice President Dick Cheney on global warming plans to criticize the administration's approach to the issue and say a senior administration official told him not to discuss dangerous consequences of rising temperatures. A22 NEW YORK/REGION A25-26 In Testimony, Lawyer Denies Aiding Terrorism Lynne F. Stewart, after sitting silently for four months while federal prosecutors portrayed her as an accomplice to her terrorist clients, spoke at her Manhattan trial for the first time, saying she was a ''very, very adversarial'' lawyer but had never crossed the line to aid violence. A1 Expanding DNA's Horizons The New York Police Department has been testing the use of DNA in investigating crimes other than rape and homicide since January. So far, it has identified 23 suspects in 34 cases, most of them burglaries that the police say would not otherwise have been solved. B1 Platform for Urban Women Miss Subways has returned, in a revival of a contest that wilted in 1976, to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the New York City subway system. But please -- it's Ms. Subways now. B4 FASHION B9 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-7 ARTS E1-8 OBITUARIES C18-19 SCIENCE TIMES F1-12 Heart Attacks Linked to Traffic Sitting in traffic nearly triples the risk of suffering a heart attack a short time later, according to a study published last week. The heightened risk may be a result of exposure to airborne pollutants that inflame the lungs and damage arteries, but the emotional stress could also be a factor. F9 Health & Fitness F5 BUSINESS DAY C1-19 Marsh's Chief Resigns Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the chief executive and chairman of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, resigned, less than two weeks after his company was accused of cheating customers. Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, said in the wake of Mr. Greenberg's departure that he would not bring criminal charges against Marsh. A1 Michael G. Cherkasky, Marsh's new chairman and chief executive, has no previous experience in the insurance business. C1 Merger Creates Steel Giant Wilbur Ross, whose buyout firm created International Steel less than two years ago, is selling the company to Lakshmi N. Mittal, the billionaire steel tycoon, for $4.5 billion. C1 Growing, but Not Booming The profit report cards last week looked good both for old-line stalwarts of technology like I.B.M. and Microsoft and for newcomers like eBay, Amazon.com and Google, but analysts have modest expectations for the technology recovery. C1 Business Digest C1 World Business W1 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Election Day mischief; making things worse; for Congress from Connecticut. Columns: Paul Krugman, David Brooks. Crossword E8 Public Lives B2 TV Listings B9 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: President George W. Bush ABORTION *Opposes abortion, except in cases of rape or incest or when a woman's life is endangered, but has said neither the country nor Congress is ready for a ban. Opposes federal funding for abortion. Signed legislation to outlaw a type of second- and third-trimester abortion procedure. *Says he would not impose an abortion ''litmus test'' on judicial appointments, but cited justices who oppose abortion rights as model appointments and says he favors ''strict constructionists.'' *Criticized F.D.A.'s approval of morning-after pill. DEATH PENALTY *Supports the death penalty. ECONOMY *Signed tax cuts in each of the past four years, including a $1.35 trillion cut over 10 years in 2001, which he wants to make permanent. Says the cuts have helped the nation overcome recession and are responsible for a surge in economic growth. The cuts have contributed to deficits expected to surpass $400 billion this year. Pledges to cut the deficit in half after five years, in part by urging Congress to limit discretionary spending except for defense and homeland security. *Would cut the corporate rate to 32 percent from 35 percent. *Wants $3,000 re-employment accounts to help with jobsearch costs. *Supports Nafta and World Trade Organization agreements. Supports liberalized trade. *Opposes an increase in the minimum wage. EDUCATION *Supports taxpayer-financed vouchers for tuition at parochial and other private schools. Signed the 2002 No Child Left Behind Act, calling for increased annual testing in third through eighth grades by 2005-2006 and tying federal funding to results of tests. *Opposes making preschool available to all 4-year-olds. *Opposes making federally backed bonds available for school repair and construction. *Signed a law providing some tax breaks for college tuition that the administration says saved students and their parents an estimated $9 billion. ENVIRONMENT *Rejected Kyoto Protocol on limiting global-warming gases on the ground it would hurt the nation's economy. Reversed a pledge to regulate carbon dioxide and proposed easing requirement that older factories and refineries to add pollution controls if they expand. *Reduced plans for drilling off the Florida coast because of local opposition. Proposed opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. FOREIGN POLICY *After the Sept. 11 attacks, instituted a policy of preemptive strikes, unilaterally if necessary, against suspected threats to the nation's security. Swift military victory in Iraq has been followed by a violent insurgency against the new government. Despite later findings that Iraq had no weapons of mass destruction and had only tenuous ties to Al Qaeda, Mr. Bush said that Saddam Hussein had the will and potential to develop such weapons and help terrorists and that ousting him has made the world safer and will encourage democracy in the Middle East. *Waged a successful war against Taliban in Afghanistan, where elections were held this month. *Won Congressional approval of $87 billion for continued military operations and aid in Iraq and Afghanistan. *Calls for a Palestinian state as part of the peace plan known as the road map. GAY RIGHTS *Opposes gay marriage. Supports a constitutional amendment defining marriage as the union between a man and a woman, but says states should decide whether to allow civil unions for gay couples. *Has continued Clinton policy allowing gays to serve in the military if they are not open about their sexuality. GUN CONTROL *Favors granting gun makers immunity from civil lawsuits arising from wrongful use of weapons. *Supports renewing the ban on assault-type weapons and requiring background checks at gun shows, but let the 10-year-old ban on assault-type weapons expire. HEALTH CARE *Signed a law giving the elderly limited prescription drug coverage under Medicare for the first time, at an estimated cost of $534 billion over the next 10 years. It subsidizes costs for low-income patients and encourages private insurance companies to offer coverage for the elderly who drop traditional Medicare. *Generally opposes importation of lower-cost drugs on grounds that the government cannot guarantee their safety. *Supports expansion of tax-free medical savings accounts. *The president's election-year budget proposes a $1,000 tax credit to help four million uninsured Americans buy health insurance. *Argued against patients' right to sue federally regulated health plans and proposes capping medical malpractice awards. HOMELAND SECURITY AND DEFENSE *After resisting Congressional demands, created a new cabinet-level position to coordinate antiterrorism efforts; tripled spending on security. *Argues that even illegal immigrants without known links to terrorist groups can be detained indefinitely. *Reconfigured the F.B.I. to focus on preventing attacks. *Signed the Patriot Act, which gave law enforcement agents expanded powers to apprehend suspects. *Hopes to deploy a shield against ballistic missiles. *Has increased defense spending by $100 billion, the most in real terms since the Korean War. *Began redeployment of troops from South Korea and Europe. Pledges he will not reinstate the draft. SOCIAL SECURITY *Favors giving younger workers choice of placing some of their Social Security payroll tax into personal retirement accounts, with potential of a higher return in exchange for smaller Social Security benefits. *Has not ruled out raising retirement age. Senator John Kerry ABORTION *Supports abortion rights and federal funding for abortion and abortion counseling. Voted against the ban on a second- and third-trimester abortion procedure because it does not allow for abortion when the life of the woman is endangered. *Says he will appoint only judges who support abortion rights to the Supreme Court. *Says health plans should assure women coverage for contraceptives. DEATH PENALTY *Opposes the death penalty, except for terrorists. ECONOMY *Would repeal Mr. Bush's tax cuts for taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and promises not to raise taxes for people earning less. Favors $18 billion a year in health care tax credits for low- and moderate-income workers, including a 75 percent credit for those earning up to 300 percent of the poverty level. *Criticizes Mr. Bush because during his presidency, the country has lost at least 585,000 jobs. Calls for $50 billion over an unspecified period for job-creation and economic-stimulus programs and tax credits to discourage outsourcing abroad. *Would cut the corporate tax rate by 5 percent. *Vows to cut deficit in half by end of first term, letting federal spending rise no more than the inflation rate except for defense, domestic security and education. *Supported North American and world trade agreements and elevated trade status with China. Would review trade agreements to assess local labor and environmental standards. *Favors an increase in the minimum wage to $7 from $5.15 by 2007 and then indexing it to inflation. EDUCATION *Opposes private-school vouchers as a drain on public school resources. Supports the 2002 legislation but says the funding has been insufficient and proposes $27 billion fully fund the act and creation of a $200 billion education trust fund. *Supports a $3.2 billion community service plan for high school students that would qualify them for the equivalent of their state's four-year public college tuition they perform two years of national service. *Favors a tax credit for college tuition costs. ENVIRONMENT *Would not sign Kyoto Protocol to cut emissions but would invest in development of hydrogen, ethanol and other cleaner renewable fuels. *Would steer $20 billion from oil and gas royalties to development of cleaner energy. *Opposes drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Wants 20 percent of electricity from renewable or alternative sources by 2020. *Supported tougher fuel-efficiency standards for vehicles. FOREIGN POLICY *Supported a Congressional resolution letting Mr. Bush go to war in Iraq but now says he did so based on faulty intelligence and assuming the president would build a broad coalition and invade as a last resort. *Voted against an $87 billion package for Iraq and Afghanistan (after voting for an earlier version that would have been paid for by repealing tax cuts for people who earn more than $200,000). Says he would begin troop withdrawal within six months and complete it within four years by enlisting more support from NATO allies. *Voted to enlarge NATO to include Eastern Europe *Sees the Bush administration's Middle East road map as an acceptable approach for reinvigorating peace efforts, but says there must be verifiable security benchmarks that the Palestinian Authority can reasonably achieve. GAY RIGHTS *Does not favor gay marriage, but opposes a constitutional amendment banning it and says individual states should decide. Supports right to civil unions for same-sex couples. Would ban job discrimination against homosexuals and extend hate-crime protections to gays. *Would let gays serve openly in the military. GUN CONTROL *Opposes granting gun makers immunity from suits. *Supports renewing the ban on assault-type weapons. *Would require the same background checks at gun shows that are mandatory for other gun sales. Supports mandatory child safety locks. HEALTH CARE *Proposes expanding health insurance coverage so that all children and 95 percent of adults are covered, at a cost to the government of $895 billion over 10 years. *Favors lowering costs of prescription drugs by allowing bulk purchasing by Medicare and easier importation of drugs from Canada. *Criticized law signed by Mr. Bush giving the elderly prescription drug coverage under Medicare as insufficient, saying it fails to directly involve the government in lowering costs. *Wants to expand the insurance system now available for federal employees to private citizens through tax credits and subsidies. *Favors a 75 percent tax credit to help pay for insurance. *Would give patients an independent review process to appeal coverage decisions. *Would bar medical malpractice suits unless a specialist ruled the claim reasonable. *Favors federal support to expand access to stateadministered health insurance for children. HOMELAND SECURITY AND DEFENSE *Voted for the Patriot Act, which gave the federal government broad new law enforcement powers; says he supports most of it, but believes it can be improved to enhance its effectiveness and prevent abuses. *Opposes a national missile defense shield. *Proposes to increase active-duty forces by 40,000 and double Army Special Forces. Would place National Guard under Homeland Security. Opposes a draft and says that reserve call-ups and orders that involuntarily extend tours of duty amount to a "backdoor draft." SOCIAL SECURITY *Opposes personal accounts under Social Security. *Opposes raising retirement age or reducing payments.

headline.main: Where They Stand, What They've Done

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County's first study of charity care in 12 local hospitals shows a wide range in the amount of free treatment given to poor patients. The largest amount was at Nassau's biggest hospital, North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset and its sibling in Syosset. Together they provided $34.6 million in charity care last year, according to the report from the Nassau County Health Department.

headline.main: Free Care For the Poor Varies Widely In Nassau

docs.snippet: Nassau County's first study of charity care in 12 local hospitals shows a wide range in the amount of free treatment given to poor patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Senator John Kerry's assault on President Bush and his policies was a machine-gun fusillade of adjectives: arrogant, bungling, cynical, ideological, inept, misleading, pathetic, reckless, shameful, stupid and above all, radically wrong. Today, it is a bombardment of numbers: health-care costs up 64 percent, college tuition up 35 percent, gas prices up 30 percent, Medicare premiums up 17 percent, prescription drug costs up 12 percent -- ''Wait, there's more,'' Mr. Kerry tells his by-now-restive crowds -- family incomes down $1,500, 1.6 million private-sector jobs lost, five million more Americans without health insurance, four million more in poverty, lost after-school programs for 500,000 children.

headline.main: Kerry's New Campaign Strategy Is Doing the Math

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry, in campaign homestretch, pivots from questioning Pres Bush's character to adding up ill effects of Bush policies, warning just how bad another four years would be, and then offering brighter vision that asks audiences to vote their hopes, not their fears; he reaches out with 'old-fashioned common sense' to make goals sound within reach and responds to Bush attacks with speeches that change by the hour; photo; Bush, by contrast, delivers same stump speech, with some punch lines kept for months (M)
docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry has pivoted from raising questions about President Bush's character to trying to add up for voters the effects of the president's policies.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has become much easier to find a job here in the last year, but few people are feeling flush. George Firestone, who locates underground cables for telephone repair crews, recently learned that he would not be getting the $1.50-an-hour wage increase he had been expecting. His wife, Nicole, has $4,000 in bills after lung surgery last year, even though they both are covered by health insurance.

headline.main: Economy Improves, but Not Optimism; In Pennsylvania, a Swing State, Few Feel Flush

docs.abstract: Economic growth and hiring continue on upswing, but soaring oil prices and persistently weak job market have made recovery more fragile and sluggish than it seemed just few months ago; middle-income consumers, who kept buying houses and cars through downturn, are now feeling squeezed between higher prices and stagnant wages; analysts estimate economy is growing at annual pace of about 4 percent, above its average trend rate; Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry, his Democratic challenger, trade dueling economic outlooks almost every day; some people in Pennsylvania, a swing state, comment; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: One week before the elections, the national economy remains stuck in a fragile and sluggish recovery.
